day.syn: >The Institute opens with a high-level view of the types of engagement required by a textual editor, beginning (always!) from the research questions and leading to the production of an actual edition. In session two we introduce the computational pipeline as a way of modeling the development of a digital edition. The afternoon sessions ground the morning’s theoretical work with a presentation of the research goals and materials to be used in the laboratory edition. We discuss document analysis and OCR as first steps in the editorial workflow. The special topic session of this first day is reserved for participants to install the software packages required to work on the laboratory edition, all of which will be provided by the Institute.

slot.title: Getting started
slot.desc: Introductions, research questions, schedules, outcome goals.

act.desc: Research questions and choosing our technologies.

outcome.goal: Make informed methodological and technical decisions based on our research questions.

act.desc: Discuss two-week schedule and day plans.
Review laboratory outcome goals and explore participant goals for their own editions.

slot.title: The edition as a computational pipeline

act.desc: We introduce the computational pipeline as a way of modeling the development of a digital edition.
Initial stages: TEI XML (base view), exploring with XPath, and exploratory data analysis (EDA).

outcome.goal: Understand base view processing and EDA.

act.desc: Transformation: how do I transform, what do I transform to? We also introduce the model-view-controller (MVC) architecture we’ll use in app development later on.

slot.title: Selecting your tools and software installation best practices
